This is the best explanation of the projection formula that I have ever seen. Prof. Strang not only provides a mathematical basis of the formula by deriving it, but also provides clear intuition and motivation. He also takes the time to go through the simpler case of projecting onto a line first, which allows building up the understanding of the content gradually. What a great lecture!
now i can feel the art of the linear algebra
Okay I figured it out. AT is not a square matrix in most cases, so it does not have an inverse. Therefore you cannot get rid of AT on both sides, because that would imply a multiplication with AT^-1.

Solution time: Sometimes we can't solve Ax=b but we can solve the nearest solution that is what projection do. But what is the link between vector b and the projection vector p, it's perpendicular. Then if b doesn't lie in the column subspace of A which will cause no solution, then we can think that the null space is also perpendicular to the column space of A. So p is in null space. Then go back to the original problem to calculate the nearest solution we just need to multiply the A' on both sides. because A'(b-Ax)=0 where b-Ax finds the A' null space, we just need to solve A'b=A'Ax. Done!

I have watched lectures 14, 15, 16 over and over again, and gain new insights each time. Professors, including mine at the university, tend to drop the arrow sign above vectors while writing on the board. This causes great confusion for the uninitiated. For example, in this lecture there is an expression "p=ax" whether the writing "ax" means a (a scalar) times x (a vector) or a (a vector) times x (a scalar) is not that obvious. Admittedly, the confusion stems from my ignorance of the commutative property of scalar multiplication of vectors, which is, in fact, not mentioned explicitly in most textbooks (e.g., Lay et al, ; Larson & Hostetler). In retrospect, this "p=ax" notation is a prelude to the ingenious way of introducing projection matrix, which again, requires pre-knowledge of associative laws. Overall, these are great lectures that stimulate thinking. Thanks a lot.

You missed the whole point of Strang’s gentle wise career which is that calculus before linear algebra is stupid and wrong, actually, linear algebra should precede calculus. We have been unnecessarily tortured and many of us our math careers destroyed, ended, by the unwise reverse decision. LA is much more comprehensible, useful, inspiring, and generally useful than calculus which I’ve never used after a PhD and 30 years more. I really wish my high school had offered linear algebra first. Then so many would have not dropped out, and would have been better served by their effortful learning.

I don't know if anyone else has noticed this, but the gradual shift into abstract concepts is done flawlessly by Professor Strang. In the first few lectures, really up until the lectures on bases, all of the methods Professor Strang uses to teach the subjects were concrete examples; very little was done with abstract definitions and arbitrary matrices. Over the last few lectures, Prof. Strang has made a gradual shift into abstractness which let's the mode of this sort of thinking sink in. Now, in this lecture, nothing is concrete and no numbers are ever used (until the end) and it feels effortless to understand! This man is a genius when it comes to math education. Thanks so much MIT and Prof. Strang for the amazing experience!

Not sure if you've figured it out yet. But in this case you're describing, the projection matrix P is being defined as the matrix that acts on the vector b to create the projection of b onto the vector a. At 8:39, you'll notice that the formula for p = a(a^Tb / A^Ta). p = Pb is just a unique grouping of that formula. It might be helpful to look at 9:40 where Strang shows the grouping he is using.

+Matt McCoy Because you know that e is perpendicular to every vector that makes the plane A and the dot product of two perpendicular vectors is 0. Therefore, since e = b - p = b - A\hat{x}, and a_1 and a_2 are in the plane A, a_1^T(b - A\hat{x}) = 0 and a_2^T(b-A\hat{x}) = 0, and finally 0=0 --> a_1^T(b - A\hat{x}) = a_2^T(b - A\hat{x}). Wai Nwe Tun Cause the column space of P is a line, therefore its dimension is 1. The column space has dimension r, so r must be 1.

Wai Nwe Tun  a * transpose(a) always has rank of a (check it yourself with a 2x1 vector by multiplying [a;b] (as letters) by the transpose of itself), and since we're working with 2x1 vectors, we know the top part of P has rank of 1 because there's only 1 column in a. The bottom can be worked out with symbolic as and bs too, but it's only going to equal a single value, thus P as a whole has rank 1.

Wai Nwe Tun P = aa^T/(a^Ta).  We don't care about the denominator a^Ta, because it's just a number (dot product).  So let's look at the numerator, aa^T.  We want to prove, for any vector x, xx^T is a square matrix that has rank 1.  Why?  Because the matrix just has columns with multiples of x (how many multiples is dictated by x^T).  So the first column is a pivot and the rest of the columns are all dependent on the first column (since they are multiples).  Hence, the rank must be 1 (the rest are free variables).

+Wai Nwe Tun| p = x * a | p is in the column space of aaT |  So when you can specify 'p' with just one vector, then the rank of the column space of aaT should also be 1. YOU ONLY NEED 'a' to find out 'p'.  YOU only need one vector to find out 'p'.

Geometrically speaking, if we want to project a vector to a line, then the rank(P) must be 1. if we want to project into a plane, then the rank(P) is 2. In the lecture, professor gave the example to project b into line vector a, so the rank is one.

Not Yupeng Su, but I will make an attempt to explain When one multiplies a matrix by a vector, as in P*x, one is actually calculating the output of a function P(x), whose input is the vector x  and  output is P*x. Now, in this example, x is a two dimensional vector. Let us write x explicitly,  [x1, x2]. This is the function's input. The output is P*x. Let us write the projection matrix P explicitly, P = [p1, p2], where p1 & p2 are column vectors. Carrying out the multiplication P*x results in x1*p1+x2*p2(this time the asterisk indicates a vector by scalar multiplication), namely, P*x is the combination/sum of the first column of P, p1, and the 2nd column of P, p2, weighted by the appropriate components of x. So, x1*p1+x2*p2 is in the column space of P.  Additionally, we know, from the geometry of the problem,  that the projection matrix, P, takes a two dimensional vector, x, and projects it onto the prescribed line vector. (*) Namely, for any vector x, x1*p1+x2*p2, the linear combination of the columns of P, lie on the chosen projection line vector. Try x=[1, 0] to get 1*p1+0*p2=p1, to show that p1 is on the line vector. Do the same for x=[0,1]. This means that both p1 and p2, lie on the line vector.  Since both p1 and p2 are vectors that point in the same direction (or lie  on the same line vector), they are dependent vectors. The dimension of a space spanned by two dependent vectors is 1.  Since these vectors are the columns of P, the rank of P , which is the dimension of its column space,  is 1.  (*) This point deserves a better explanation, that may by given by the lecturer later on in the course.

P = a.a^t which means that all columns of P are merely multiples of the column contained in a. So the rank of P must be 1. Also, rank of a = 1 and thus, rank of a^t is also 1. Thus their product must have a rank 1.

Not always: (A^T)A is only invertible if the columns of A are independent! Let A be any m by n matrix. If the n columns of A are independent, then its rank is n, so (A^T)A is an n by n matrix of rank n, which means it's a full rank square matrix, which is equivalent to saying that it's invertible. In practice, if you have a lot of rows (observations) and only a few columns (variables), (A^T)A is invertible when the variables are not correlated.

To make it more clear, we want to project b into the column space of A because b is not in the column space of A, which means A is not invertible. If A is invertible, we event don't need to project b, as the columns space of A covers the whole space in R^n.

Keep in mind that the matrix A that the professor uses is made up of only the basis vectors of the subspace, and as @ocococoe  pointed out, if the the columns of  A are independent, A'A  will always be invertible.
